title: 111_s2336
content: The Act titled "USA PATRIOT Reauthorization Act of 2009" includes provisions for the improvement and reauthorization of the USA PATRIOT Act. The USA PATRIOT Improvement and Reauthorization Act of 2005 is amended to change the year from 2009 to 2013. Additionally, amendments are made to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 and the FISA Amendments Act of 2008. The USA PATRIOT Improvement and Reauthorization Act of 2005 is amended to change the year from 2009 to 2013, with amendments to the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 and the FISA Amendments Act of 2008. Effective December 31, 2013, access to records under specified sections is modified. SEC. 3. Extension of sunset for individual terrorists as agents of foreign powers. The text chunk discusses the amendment to the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 regarding the sunset provision of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. Subparagraph (C) of section 101(b)(1) is repealed effective December 31, 2013, but a transition provision allows it to continue for ongoing investigations or offenses before that date. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to align with the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004, with the effective date set for December 31, 2013. SEC. 4. JUDICIAL REVIEW OF NATIONAL SECURITY LETTERS. Section 3511(b) of title 18, United States Code is amended regarding nondisclosure requirements for recipients of requests for information under various acts. If a recipient wishes to challenge a nondisclosure requirement, they must notify the Government within 30 days. The Government can apply for a nondisclosure order upon receiving a notification under subparagraph (A) in the district court of the United States where the authorized investigation is taking place. The court should rule promptly and issue a nondisclosure order, which remains in effect during related proceedings. The Government can apply for a nondisclosure order in the district court of the United States where the authorized investigation is taking place. The order includes conditions appropriate to the circumstances and requires a certification from specified officials indicating potential danger to national security without disclosure. The district court of the United States can issue a nondisclosure requirement order if there is reason to believe that disclosure of certain information will result in danger to national security, interference with investigations, diplomatic relations, or danger to a person's safety. The district court can issue a nondisclosure order if disclosure poses a threat to national security, investigations, diplomatic relations, or a person's safety.
